abstract.p: This article is concerned with a probabilistic mesoscale damage detection in polycrystals. For this purpose, we make use of a stochastic model describing the linear elasticity matrix of material at the mesoscale. The model is constructed using a maximum entropy principle and random matrix theory and allows one to directly construct a probabilistic model for the system random matrices characterizing the constitutive behavior of the system. First, the theoretical framework and upscale scheme in the construction of the model are briefly reviewed. For each case of healthy and damaged materials, where the damage is introduced in the form of intergranular microcavities, the random matrix model is calibrated by performing simulations on an ensemble of statistical volume elements of microstructure. The calibrated models are then used in a simple coarse-scale simulation in order to explore the sensitivity of the model in detecting the location of mesoscale damages. The result shows that in most cases, one can identify the location of cracks by comparing the probabilistic description of a suitable response quantity of interest predicted for both healthy and damaged systems. Such a probabilistic description is suitable for detecting signature of fine-scale defects where the consequences are reflected at the coarse scale in the form of random fluctuations around the mean behavior. The model can be used as a predictive tool in the context of structural health monitoring and damage prognosis of metallic systems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the past decade, significant research efforts have been conducted in the area of structural health monitoring of aerospace structures in order to develop onboard systems for integrated health management and damage diagnosis (Farrar et al., 2006; Farrar and Lieven, 2006; Inman et al., 2005). With the advances in sensor technology, material characterization, and computational capabilities, the research and development in this field have been focused on introducing hierarchical frameworks of sensor data, information, models, and algorithms that span and integrate scales from the microstructure to the system level. The quantification of damage requires sensor information being interpreted in terms of hierarchy of damage accumulation models, which effectively represent the material and structural changes that occur during the lifetime of the system. An essential component of such a framework is a computationally efficient model to predict the mechanical behavior of the system during its lifetime. A crucial characteristic of such a model is its ability to quantify the variability in the mechanical response. In metallic structures, this variability is often due to the microstructural heterogeneities, which are connected to the fluctuation in the texture or other morphological features of materials as well as the potential presence of anomalies such as microcracks or other types of subscale defects. Thus, the model behavior, on the one hand, needs to be sensitive to the subscale heterogeneities in order to predict the phenomena occurring at the early stage of damage initiation. On the other hand, the state of the model needs to be amenable to comparison with experimental observables. The effect of subscale defects is reflected on the coarse-scale observables in the form of random fluctuations around the average response. Thus, the model must account for these fluctuations in order to capture the signature of subscale heterogeneities. A probabilistic approach is beneficial to adequately model the variation in observable quantities that could be linked to the presence of damage in the early stage. Such a probabilistic model can then be combined with the finite element analysis to serve as a predictive tool in the system level in the context of structural health monitoring and damage prognosis.

Recently, a stochastic multiscale procedure is adopted to model the mesoscale elasticity tensor of polycrystalline materials (Das and Ghanem, 2009; Guilleminot et al., 2011) using a random matrix approach. Making use of the maximum entropy (MaxEnt) principle and random matrix theory, this approach allows one to construct a probabilistic model for the system random matrices characterizing the constitutive behavior of the system. The calibration and validation of the model using simulated data were presented in Noshadravan et al.’s (in press) study. For this purpose, first, a surrogate model was constructed to further experimental measurement on the geometry and the crystallography of the polycrystalline microstructure. In order to explore the suitability of the model as a predictive tool for the purpose of structural health monitoring and damage prognosis, the sensitivity of the model responses to the presence of fine-scale damages must be examined. The main goal of this article is to address the application of this probabilistic representation in detecting the signature of microscale defects in polycrystalline materials.

The article is organized as follows: In section “Stochastic modeling of mesoscale elasticity tensor,” we present the ingredients for the stochastic modeling of the mesoscale elasticity tensor using a random matrix approach. We first briefly review the theoretical framework for the construction of the model. Then, we discuss the calibration of the model for the case of healthy material as well as material with defects, where defects are introduced as intergranular microcavities. Finally, in section “Mesoscale damage detection,” we present the application of the model in coarse-scale simulations for the purpose of damage detection.

sec.title: Stochastic modeling of mesoscale elasticity tensor
sec.p: This section is concerned with the probabilistic modeling of apparent elasticity matrix for heterogeneous materials with microstructures. For this purpose, we make use of a MaxEnt-based approach to directly construct a random model of system matrices characterizing the continuum elasticity matrix of material at the mesoscale. This is the scale for which the characteristic length is smaller than the representative volume element (RVE). The construction and identification of such a probabilistic description in the context of mesoscale modeling of polycrystalline microstructures have been presented in detail in studies of Das and Ghanem (2009) and Guilleminot et al. (2011) and will be briefly reviewed in this section.

sec.title: Upscaling mechanical properties
sec.p: The ingredients of the upscaling scheme for modeling the overall response of material with microstructures are reviewed here. This procedure allows one to construct the constitutive law at the coarse scale, while taking into account available information on the fine-scale features. The resulting representation is used to model the scatter observed at the macroscale of some physical behavior of interest that is directly linked to phenomena occurring at the scale of heterogeneity, and consequently, it can be well adapted to capture the signature of microscale anomaly, for example, defects and damages, without performing detailed fine-scale simulations.

sec.title: Probabilistic models
sec.p: Two slightly different random matrix models are used in this study to characterize the mesoscale elasticity of polycrystals with and without defects. The theoretical framework for model construction is briefly reviewed to highlight the difference in the structure of these models. The procedure for calibration of these two models is then discussed, which involves performing micromechanical analysis on a set of SVEs of digitally simulated microstructures.

sec.title: Simulation of database
sec.p: Calibration of the mesoscale probabilistic model described in the previous section requires the experimental test or micromechanical analysis performed on a set of SVEs of microstructure subjected to the appropriate boundary conditions. In this study, we make use of a statistical model for digitally simulating two-dimensional (2D) polycrystalline microstructure in accordance with the experimental measurements. The model is based on the Voronoi tessellation technique (Okabe, 2000; Stoyan et al., 1987) that is widely used in the mechanics and physics of random media as a simple representation of 2D polycrystalline microstructures in metallic alloys (Arwade and Grigoriu, 2004; Ostoja Starzewski, 2008). We particularly make use of a modified Poisson–Voronoi tessellation (Scheike, 1994) for representing the random geometry of polycrystals with elongated grains and a vector-valued random field to model the spatially correlated crystallographic orientations. For characterization purposes, the microstructure is described by the equivalent aspect ratios and the Euler angle representation of crystallographic orientations for all the grains. The model is calibrated using an experimental measurement on geometry and crystallography of approximately 4000 grains extracted from electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) (Adams, 1993; Schwartz et al., 2000) maps of aluminum alloy 2024-T351 (Parra Garcia et al., 2008). The detail of model construction is presented elsewhere (Noshadravan et al., 2013) and is not repeated here for the sake of brevity. This statistical model essentially provides a surrogate to further experimental data required for the calibration and validation of the mesoscale probabilistic model. Figure 1 shows an experimental realization of EBSD map. A typical realization of digitally generated microstructure is also shown in Figure 2.

sec.title: Model calibration for the polycrystal with intergranular microcavities
sec.p: In order to illustrate the use of random matrix approach in detecting the signature of fine-scale damage, one also needs to identify a random matrix description for the mesoscale elasticity tensor of material with damage. Such a description could be dependent upon the representation of damage in the material. When the experimental data are available, the model can be calibrated from, for instance, inversion of ultrasonic wave velocities on fatigue-induced samples. Minimal parameterization of the model can facilitate experimental identification. In the absences of such experimental measurements, in this study, we make use of a simple representation for damaged medium in which elongated microcavities are introduced along the grain boundary. Note that the use of simulated data could introduce a modeling bias in the identification process. However, the effect of this representation, which is reflected on linear elastic properties in the form of reduction in homogenized mesoscale stiffness, is consistent with what is observed in experimental setting, and the general approach for the use of random matrix modeling for damage detection in engineering application would be similar. In this section, we address the calibration of a random matrix model for mesoscale elasticity matrix of damaged material due to the presence of microscale defects in the form of random intergranular microcavities. The grain boundaries are a potential location for the initiation of microcracks. The effect of these defects is reflected on mesoscale properties in the form of degradation in overall elastic stiffness of SVEs. Since the apparent elasticity in this scale is random in nature and since the defects are introduced in a random fashion, the apparent elasticity tensor of the damaged SVE is obviously random. At this point, it is worth mentioning again that the bounds on the apparent elasticity matrix are not well defined for a heterogeneous material containing holes and cavities. Hence, for the case of damaged material, we employ the probabilistic model for unbounded elasticity tensor as given by equation (11).

Before utilizing the random matrix model as a predictive tool in structural level application for the purpose of detection and prognosis, the model needs to be validated from the perspective of its intended uses. This step involves evaluating the level of agreement between model predictions and the observations with respect to a desired response quantity of interest. The validation task for the mesoscale probabilistic model used in this study has been addressed in detail in Noshadravan et al.’s (2013) study. For this purpose, the model was employed to perform simulation on a coarse-scale representation of a medium with mesoscale randomness, and the response predictions were compared to simulated data resulting from fine-scale representation of the domain with grain scale randomness. Comparing the probabilistic description of the response quantity of interest in the form of volume-averaged strain energy density, it was found that the variation in the model predictions is sufficiently consistent with the observations (Noshadravan et al., 2013). In the following section, the capability of the model in detection of damages and defects will be discussed. This part constitutes the first step in demonstrating the application of the presented probabilistic representation in performing system-level simulations for the purpose of structural health monitoring and damage prognosis.

sec.title: Mesoscale damage detection
sec.p: The probabilistic models discussed in the previous section provide compact stochastic representations describing the local homogenized linear elastic behavior of heterogeneous materials. The model is identified through a calibration process performed on a specific mesoscale with fine-scale resolution. It is worth noting that the effect of fine-scale statistical fluctuations is smoothed out at the mesoscale and cannot be accounted. The model, however, allows accommodating the statistical fluctuations at the mesoscale that is connected to the subscale features and propagating the consequence induced at the macroscale. The sensitivity of the model to subscale heterogeneities is the key to its applicability in predicting phenomena occurring at the damage initiation scale. The present section aims at demonstrating the use of this stochastic material description in detecting the signature of mesoscale damage.

sec.p: It should be pointed out that the presented case study is intended to examine the sensitivity of the random matrix model in detecting the signature of mesoscale damages and, as such, is the first step to explore the capability of the approach in predictive modeling in the context of structural health monitoring and prognosis. It is worth noting that the performance of the model could be linked to the representation of damage in the calibration step as well as the complexity of polycrystalline microstructure. Further research is required to shed light on the efficiency of the approach for a variety of materials with different morphological and microstructural features.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: In this article, we have presented a probabilistic mesoscale damage detection in polycrystals using a random matrix model. For this purpose, we make use of a stochastic model describing the linear elasticity matrix of material at the mesoscale. The theoretical framework and upscaling scheme in the construction and calibration of the random matrix model are briefly reviewed. In order to show the application of such a stochastic upscaling scheme in damage detection, we identified two random matrix models representing the mesoscopic description of polycrystalline material with and without defects. The defects are introduced in the form of intergranular microcavities. We then used these random matrix models in coarse-scale simulations of a heterogeneous cantilever beam with mesoscale randomness. For the purpose of damage detection, we solved boundary value problem using Monte Carlo simulations for a healthy beam as well as a beam containing damaged elements. The PDFs of averaged strain energy density in different locations were computed and compared for both cases. By looking at the discrepancy between the PDFs for healthy and damaged systems, the potential location of damages can be identified. The result indicates that in most cases, the random matrix model is capable of detecting the region containing damaged elements. Moreover, by looking at the strain energy density averaged over smaller domain, one can localize the damage in the detected region. Thus, for the material under study, the random matrix approach can be suitable in detecting signature of fine-scale defects where the consequences are reflected at the coarse scale in the form of random fluctuations around the mean behavior. The presented study aims to explore the capability of the approach in predictive modeling in the context of structural health monitoring and prognosis. It is worth noting that the performance of the model could be linked to the representation of damage in the calibration step as well as the complexity of polycrystalline microstructure. Further research is required to shed light on the efficiency of the approach for variety of engineering materials with different morphological and microstructural features.
